title: Wednesday, 30th January 2019
bodyHTML:
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Hi, sorry, late. Methode's not working. Gimme a moment.

Blank canvas good morning BE et al - what market treats do you have for us today?
VV75 morning
Soundbuy Morning
BE11:15am

Gah, still not responding. Bloody thing.

BE11:15am

Manxish Morning each
Shinshin Morning. Anything on LSE buying Euroclear ?
11:15 am
BE11:15am

It's irritating when my day job gets in the way of my other day job.

BE11:15am

Right, anyway, let's kick on.

DogDay morning all
Badger so it's a to-day job?
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Good morning.
BE11:16am

And I'll try to release that as soon as the machines decide to work.

11:16 am
undefined
BE11:16am

Brexit, then!

BE11:17am

So yesterday the FTSE had a big rally on the idea that no-deal was moving further away as a possibility.

VV75 on second thought, let's not go there. Tis a silly place"
11:17 am
BE11:17am

And today the FTSE's having a big rally on the idea that no-deal has moved closer as a possibility.

BE11:18am

But .... um .... general election less likely? So we're up 1.3%, largely sterling powered.

red ft100 is more sterling related. 2 hours ago cable dipped and the main index began to rally a bit.
red still, MPs have used yesterdays votes well to show where they stand
BE11:19am

(@Red: really? Tell me more why don't you.)

11:19 am
Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,337, up 78.67 (+3.48%), High: 2,358, Low: 2,248, Volume: 188.05k
red ball in EU court now at least. after 2 years of dithering
British American Tobacco PLC (BATS:LSE): Last: 2,586, up 76.03 (+3.03%), High: 2,596, Low: 2,528, Volume: 1.62m
BE11:20am

And the miners, of course, which didn't react particularly to the Vale news but seem to be very responsive to FX

11:20 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 304.15, up 7.1 (+2.39%), High: 305.15, Low: 300.00, Volume: 13.56m
Fresnillo PLC (FRES:LSE): Last: 986.62, up 21.22 (+2.20%), High: 997.80, Low: 969.80, Volume: 286.18k
rw42 i must have seen a different vote - what MPs voted for is vague garbage that the EU won't like, and as soon as they specify exactly what they want, May will lose support again. Sort of a Heisenburg agreement..
red well, cooper amendment, which would have given MPs more power to set agenda and also extend art50 failed right. but spelman amendment was passed. this a bit of a free vote as wasnt binding, so folks could vote how they really felt. as not wanting a no deal. then brady was passed, essentially giving may one last chance to chnage the back stop. so MPs are prepared to back Mays deal but with a chnage to backstop.
Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous and assorted people. Is there a tech industry in Canada outside Vancouver and Toronto?
Finlay I think they've shown where they don't stand, rather than where they do. They've effectively rejected May's deal again, without saying what should stand in its place, just in a whole new way
BE11:22am

Which I guess is on the continuing idea that as Brexit moves further to the wire, the wire won't be a garotte.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

WANT SOME PROBABILITIES? GOD ALMIGHTY I DO!

BE11:22am

Here's Goldman.

BE11:22am

On our reading of last night’s Commons votes, Parliament at large signalled that it opposes a “no deal” Brexit, but that it is not ready to delay Brexit to rule out “no deal” entirely. The Eurosceptic wing of the Conservative Party, by contrast, signalled that it opposes the Prime Minister’s Brexit deal, and it is ready to risk “no deal” to re-negotiate the terms on offer. All in all, we revise up our subjective probability of a “no deal” Brexit slightly (from 10% to 15%), we keep our subjective probability of a delayed Brexit deal unchanged (at 50%), and we mark down our subjective probability of “no Brexit” (from 40% to 35%).

BornCynic Morning
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Just the 35% chance then. Super. And Citi:

cloudy Anyone would think we're not in the European Union.
BE11:24am

Tonight’s results maximize the Prime Minister’s bargaining power in Brussels under the given constraints by revealing a majority for a version of the exit treaty visually close to the current one. By not legally ruling out no-deal, May can continue to try and use mutual economic damage as a bargaining chip to get concessions from the EU27. At the margin, the result revives the chances of an orderly Brexit on 29 March or soon thereafter. The unity of the Conservative Party also materially reduces the risk of early elections and thus the likelihood of Jeremy Corbyn becoming PM soon.

BE11:24am

The failure to pass the Cooper amendment extends no-deal risk. Perhaps it has even increased as no further Brexit vote is currently scheduled (however, Theresa May pledged to table an amendable statement, if not a new deal, on 13/14 February). No-deal Brexit is once again the legal default. The fact that the UK economy seems to be holding up while the EU economy is weakening may encourage the UK side to take negotiations to the wire.

Badger But don't worry- Boris is confident May can do the job. Which of course means he's certain she won't and then they'll need a new leader. If only there was someone who could pick ups he balls if not came loose from the scrum..
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Tonight’s results are unlikely to constitute a viable negotiating strategy for the government. The unity of its parliamentary backers could splinter quickly if the EU rejects renegotiating the Northern Ireland backstop. Further economic consequences of the protracted uncertainty are still likely and may undermine unity. Parliament retains the power to withdraw confidence in the government and replace it or call new elections. An Article 50 TEU extension is still a highly likely scenario.

BE11:25am

UK politics remain unpredictable and many scenarios remain possible, including early elections or a second referendum. Citi’s Chief Global Political Analyst reckons that today’s results point to a shift in probabilities towards an early election and against a second referendum in the second half of the year.

Shinshin GS no-deal from 10% to 15% ? Sheesh. Surely from 30% to 45% is more feasible.
GBKrona Should be a huge plus that likelihood of Corbyn as PM goes down further every day. He was utterly useless yesterday.
BE11:25am

Imagine all the stuff we could get done if we weren't permanently buried in this shite.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Anyway.

undefined
Pharma The majority of MPs clearly want to ignore the referendum result and stay in the EU. They are afraid to say this openly, so they pretend to want an unattainable deal. Hence the votes last night.
Lemmy They're rejected May's deal yes but also signalled they'd vote for May's deal if the backstop could be replaced. But without saying what the replacement should look like. At least things are, for now, crystallised to resolving this NI issue.
red @Shinshinyes i think many have around 1/3 risk. its the default result after all so can never be ruled out.
BE11:26am

Okay, Methode's back up. I'll attempt to get a tad less grumpy. What we got corporate wise?

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I'm really tired of Brexit. I feel ill by it.
GBKrona @BE Given very few UK results, any comment on Santander please?
Mouselet Lots of US tech results announcements, none of them terribly surprising; AMD appears to be doing surprisingly OK and nVidia appears to have overstretched itself.
Pharma @Lemmy May's deal minus the backstop still much worse than staying in (speaking as someone who wants to leave)
red eu unlikely to budge until v last minute at best. so i suspect any cooper type amendment in two weeks time gets passed. so sterling continues to be a buy on the next dip that comes.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Someone was wanting LSE and their Euroclear purchase, which feels sensible rather than interesting.

VV75 May's bluff has been called time and time again. because she has nothing to bluff with in Brussels, regardless of what still-living-in-imperial-britain Bojo might think.
London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE:LSE): Last: 4,559, up 29 (+0.64%), High: 4,567, Low: 4,512, Volume: 142.14k
BE11:28am

4.9% stake for €279m.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Statement talks about how being a shareholder will "strengthen LSEG and Euroclear's existing operational and commercial relationship"

qwerty STAFFLINEThe Company announces that publication of the results for the year ended 31 December 2018 has been delayed. No explanation so shares fall 23%!
BE11:29am

Now, there has been considerable talk over the years about whether a Euroclear-LSE merger would make sense.

BE11:30am

This is not that, to be clear. But it's a very small move in that direction based on the same logic. Here's UBS:

Forester I love all the clever use of words - "EU will not re-open the deal"....talk of a codicil being appended to the deal re the ackstop so technically not re-opening it!
11:30 am
BE11:30am

LSE (under its former CEO, Xavier Rolet) viewed collateral management as a key growth opportunity. As the holder of more than €28 trillion of assets, Euroclear is the largest depository of securities (and potential collateral) in Europe. This stake acquisition could, in theory, lead to the development of a collateral management solution provided by LSE to Euroclear customers.

Flaneur @rw42 - (playing catch up here) 'Heisenburg agreement' - lol
BE11:31am

And Cazenove.

Soundbuy Staffline - silence a tad deafening..........obviuos the share price would be savaged so why??
BE11:31am

The rationale for the minority investment is to strengthen LSE's and Euroclear's existing operational and commercial relationships. The transaction will be funded from existing cash and debt facilities and the net debt/EBITDA will remain within the 1-2x target post completion. The transaction is to be earnings accretive. In our view, this deal seems more sensible than the previously speculated deal for the LSE to acquire Oslo (which Nasdaq has announced a bid for today, following on from the previous bid from Euronext)

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Speaking of!

FATDAZ BE will be interesting to hear cazenove thoughts as Euroclear was once a JPM property
BornCynic OK BE - "sensible rather than interesting" - what do you have in your inbox that is interesting please?
BE11:32am

Nasdaq counterbid for Oslo Bors and getting irrevocables from shareholders representing 35.1%.

Pharma One scenario I haven't seen mentioned in the press.If the government looses a vote of no confidence within three weeks of the 29th March, then an election will be called, but we will leave with no deal during the campaign.Corbyn wouldn't object, and maybe enough ERG-types would cross the floor to pass the vote.
BE11:33am

Nasdaq offering NOK 152 in cash per share in Oslo against NOK 145 offered by Euronext.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Back to Caz .....

BE11:33am

For Euronext, we estimate the Oslo deal would be c12% earnings accretive (pre synergies) in 2020, compared to 3% accretive in 2020 for Nasdaq.

BE11:33am

So, plenty of room for another bump.

11:33 am
undefined
BE11:34am

Staffline? Who knows!

Gary the Geezer Any grey on LVMH? Thanks BE
Staffline Group PLC (STAF:LSE): Last: 778.48, down 221.52 (-22.15%), High: 973.00, Low: 760.00, Volume: 94.44k
FATDAZ @BE haven't Nasdaq come a cropper when investing in Scandinavia before
11:34 am
BE11:35am

The CEO and CFO had a roadshow scheduled to begin today.

Shinshin Thanks BE on LSE
Badger anything on Mike Ashley and Sofa.com? Thanks.

Which remained the case yesterday, as far as I know, so whatever's appeared to delay the numbers seems to have appeared at rather short notice.

PBateman is Lseg not going for Oslo Bors then?
PBateman heard rumours it was
Soundbuy Surely Ashley has enough on his plate..............unless he needs a sit-down.........
PBateman Does anyone genuinely see the EU reopening the withdrawal agreement now?
Soundbuy No
VV75 @PBateman, nope

A reminder that Staffline is built largely from acquisitions and relies on a lot of public and quango contracts, which bring their own complications to the numbers.

11:40 am

Though if Staffline management had any reason to believe that a false market existed in the stock based on current information the onus would be on them to suspend. So ....... Who knows! I don't.

undefined
BE11:42am

PBateman, re Oslo Bors-LSE, that idea was widely reported slightly more than a week ago.

PBateman Which leaves us on an A50 extension to nowhere?
Finlay No - they can't show weakness either and I think they're fairly sure that MP's will blink first.
PBateman What i'm finding very interesting is how well the UK economy has held up vs the continent
PBateman Amidst all of this
11:43 am
BE11:43am

The general idea then was that they'd take a look but wouldn't get drawn into an auction. Today's events seem to lessen the chances of a bid considerably.

BE11:43am

Back to UBS.

BE11:43am

While an Oslo Børs acquisition would be accretive to LSE's EPS in our range of scenarios, we question whether LSE will pursue this target aggressively. Given Oslo Børs' solicitation for competing bids from other exchanges, we suspect LSE is merely examining the merits of a potential deal. The acquisition of a European cash equity exchange has not been in line with LSE's recent strategy to expand into higher-value exchange businesses (indices, OTC clearing). That said, with a new CEO in place, referencing LSE's previous strategy may be presumptive.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Oslo Børs currently licenses LSE's Millennium trading systems technology for its cash equity and fixed income business [it licenses technology from the Montreal Exchange for its derivatives business].

BE11:44am

We would expect this to limit the potential expense synergies available to LSE, which would be available to other exchanges operating proprietary in-house platforms [such as ENXT and Nasdaq]. As a result, we reduce the potential cost saves by £5m in each of our scenarios to reflect the weaker opportunity for LSE. For example, that means we give LSE credit for expense synergies equivalent to 30% of Oslo Børs' expense base in our upside case [vs. 40% for Euronext based on the upper bound of expense synergies achieved in historical exchange-to-exchange M&A].

undefined
PBateman Unprecedented economic and political uncertainty, yet simultaneously nearly unprecedented levels of employment and wage growth at multi-year highs.. what gives?
pancakes or waffles wasn't the european economy doing much better tho vis-a-vis the UK a year or so ago though? dont follow UK closely so must admit i am in the dark here...
GBKrona @BE - Anything on Santander please
11:46 am
BE11:46am

I have nothing to offer on Mike Ashley apparently going into the sale of Sofa.com.

BE11:46am

Santander, however, I can help with.

PBateman thanks BE, interesting
BE11:47am

Shares flattish on my screen, assuming I'm looking at the right quote. Q4's ahead of consensus.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Pre provision profit ~4% ahead on better results in Spain and some emerging markets.

Pharma @pancakes, but wasn't that widely put down to QE from ECB. Certainly growth seems to have stopped pretty much the same time as the monetary taps were turned off.
BE11:48am

None of which matters overly because all that matters with Santander is the capital position

BE11:49am

And there, we get a microscopic improvement.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Kepler incoming:

BE11:49am

CET1 fully loaded improved from 10.8% to 11.0% (excluding IFRS 9, which
is 27bps). 10bps is organic generation and 9bps is the sale of Wizink. After
a 40% RWA decline in the corporate centre on model changes in Q3, group
RWA grew by 6% in the quarter. We expect the company to detail impacts
of IFRS16, TRIM and Popular securitisations in the call. TBVPS reported by
the company is EUR4.19 (vs EUR4.16), but TBVPS must be recalculated
using annual report data as Santander excludes some intangibles and also
includes some CoCos in its TBVPS calculation (which is below EUR4). We
value Santander with a traditional Gordon growth model. COE is a blend of
the COE of countries (10.7%). G of 3%. We use a long-term ROTE of 9.5%,
long-term equivalent to the long-term range vs. the average hit to capital
from currency depreciations. We adjust our EPS for 2019E and 2020E by -
5% to take into account the economic slowdown in developed economies.

Bull/bear Santander like to quote their CET1 ratio to the second decimal - always looks a tad desperate!
VV75 Wizzair grey please, if you have any?
Mouselet I do wonder what a world with much less QE from European and Chinese centres looks like
BE11:50am

Beyond that, a few notes from the conference call. This is via Goldman.

Penny @pbateman, i think the EU will 'flex' a bit after a protracted dance
11:50 am
BE11:51am

A ‘no deal’ Brexit would negatively impact its new ROTE target range [13%-15%] as it has not incorporated that scenario; in the short run, it has fully hedged UK earnings for FY19.

PBateman europe's slowdown has strengthened our hand imo
pancakes or waffles @Pharma true, i am no macro specialist. i do think the recent slowdown can be partly attributed to transitory factors as well like WLTP impacting growth in germany for example
BE11:51am

And on the divi, slightly disappointing.

PBateman very surprised to see Varadkar being so uncompromising
PBateman https://www.finance.gov.ie/updates/minister-donohoe-outlines-initial-assessment-of-economic-and-fiscal-impact-of-no-deal-brexit/
BE11:51am

Reiterated full cash dividend with a payout at 30%-40% in 2019 and beyond (our estimate: 50% in 2019E).

PBateman massive shock to Éire on no deal - forecasts out a couple of days ago
GBKrona thanks @BE for Santander
pancakes or waffles and growth slowdown has also coincided with China slowing ... so dont think its all due to ECB slowing the taps
11:52 am
BE11:52am

And Exane to grumble about how none of it matters anyway.

BE11:53am

The company managed to deliver a ROTE of 11.7% during 2018, approximately in line with the cost of capital we apply to the business model. Unfortunately, the ROTE metric has lost all its value as a guide to shareholderreturns, in our opinion, given the losses booked straight through the equity base.

BE11:53am

According to our estimates, SAN’s TE per share plus dividends increased by 8% during 2018 and has increased at an average p.a. rate of just 6% over the past seven years. That is, in our opinion, the real return investors are getting. The evolution of EPS, EPS volatility and the reported ROTE are not relevant, in our opinion, in terms of analysing the potential value of the company. The company’s medium term 13%-15% ROTE target could be reached (depending on the amount of losses booked straight through the equity base), but in our opinion we are unlikely to see such growth in terms of TE per share plus dividends.

SS16 The Irish, north and south aren't usually great ones for compromise
Pharma @pancakes, yes, there is that and the yellow vest movement in France to take some of the blame. But I think 1.5%+ 2019 growth forecasts for the eurozone will prove to be wildly optimistic. China is not going back to 7%+ growth any time soon, which leaves Germany with a shrinking market.
11:53 am
BE11:53am

They're underperform, target down to E4.4

undefined
BE11:54am

Oh, while on banks, just gonna flag Goldman on Metro.

11:54 am
Metro Bank PLC (MTRO:LSE): Last: 1,233, down 112 (-8.33%), High: 1,377, Low: 1,233, Volume: 504.10k
PBateman was surprised to see a +0.3% gdp print from France given Gilets Jaunes
pancakes or waffles agreed. just to make it clear, i am not wildly bullish EU either, just maybe not as pessimistic as some. neutral would be best way to describe it i guess
PBateman Paris service industry ground to a halt for a sustained period
BE11:55am

Goldman was on the float, of course, and the note here mostly says the blindingly obvious.

BornCynic I don't know. Brexit is everywhere. Just listening to Dixons analyst and investor call and Goldman asked them about their preparations for Brexit. They are increasing stock levels by 30-40 million - Brexit appears to be costing everyone money......
BE11:55am

[Last week's warning] raises three key concerns: (1) Falling industry profitability (fin-reg driven, in our view) has reduced UK banks’ profitability, and with it Metro’s organic capital generation capacity; (2) higher risk-weights imply higher capital consumption than previously estimated; and (3) taken together, this results in a diminished ability to self-fund the current pace of growth. We believe Metro has three levers it can alter in response to this: (1) Adjust growth, (2) adjust margins or (3) consider an increase in capital.

Penny @pbateman, interesting story on rival service re gilets jaunes:https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-25/yellow-vest-fears-said-to-steer-macron-against-no-deal-brexit
11:58 am
BE11:58am

The broader question now is what Metro plans to do, and until we know that it's a binary call because we can't realistically expect it to raise cash under TNAV.

Pharma @BornCynic for a company that sources it's stuff almost exclusively from outside the EU that is bizarre.
BE11:59am

Goldman's target comes back to £17, a level where a rights issue remains possible. The current price is a tad more challenging.

undefined
11:59 am
BE11:59am

Wizz Air? Sure. The results are irrelevant.

PBateman I think BE mentioned but we could see a really strong UK GDP number in Feb on forward purchases / stockpiling
Wizz Air Holdings PLC (WIZZ:LSE): Last: 3,141, up 91 (+2.98%), High: 3,178, Low: 2,901, Volume: 361.60k
Mouselet I don't think containers from Shanghai via Rotterdam get special exemption in the traffic jam
Mouselet Or even containers from Shanghai straight to Felixstowe
BE12:00pm

Fuel costs went stratospheric over the three months and erased quarterly earnings, but as Wizz hit its year-end guidance after six months it simply doesn't matter.

BornCynic @Pharma - Brexit now like the panic round Y2K?
PBateman Comin' thru, got a pallet load of HP laptops on board (non-eu), out my way
Pharma @Mouselet, just, that thought just struck me. Be interesting to see exactly how much of our "EU trade" is actually stuff from China being shipped via the continent.Note that none of the european port operators expect any delays, deal or no deal.
Mouselet If we'd segregated ports into from-EU and from-RoW decades ago ...
Blank canvas Noon day gun. Gin glasses are primed. Thanks for everything today.
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

A simple repeat of today's (very underwhelming) Q3 in Q4 and it's going to come in above the range. That's how seasonal this business is.

PBateman It's OK, Seabourne Freight will pick up the slack no doubt
BE12:01pm

Let me find someone on the sellside to say that.

hornblower @BE - why can't Metro raise capital below book value? technical or regulatory or just looks really bad
BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
BE12:03pm

Davy? Davy.

Curious Are Metro's issues likely to be similar at other challenger banks?
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Wizz Air’s Q3 release is largely as expected, in our view. The less
meaningful December quarter was slightly weaker but costphasing
had an effect and, importantly, the full-year net income
guide was maintained (at €270-300m). Fuel and pricing continue
to show a link, which is also encouraging, and we think that the
company is well placed for a strong FY 2020 period.

BE12:03pm

Wizz Air has reported net income of €1.7m in Q3 FY 2019, modestly lower than
last year (Q3 FY 2018: €14m), albeit in a less meaningful quarter. Revenue of
€512.7m rose 21% year-on-year (yoy) (Q3 FY 2018: €423m) with the main drivers
being capacity growth of 15.0% (as guided), a strong performance on loads
(+1.9pts to 91.5%) and total RASK +5.6% (we estimate circa +6.2% at constant
currency (ccy)). Within this, ancillaries per passenger were up 6% due to changes
in the baggage policy through winter, while yields per RPK were up 3%.
Ex-fuel CASK was up 4.0%, while fuel CASK rose 22%. Regarding ex-fuel CASK,
we note that the maintenance of the full-year guide (at -1%) implies that there are
phasing effects which disadvantaged Q3. Notably, disruption costs were €5.9m in
Q3 (versus €7.9m in Q3 FY 2018) as on-time performance improved to 80.4% in
Q3 versus 72.1% in H1 and only 79 flights were cancelled versus 251 in H1.
Full-year net income guidance has been maintained at €270-300m (consensus:
€300m). In terms of the components, capacity is still guided at +17% for the year,
although Wizz has suggested the aircraft utilisation will pick up again in FY 2020.
Fuel CASK is guided at +19% (previous: +22%) with the jet fuel price (currently
circa $600pmt versus $720pmt) having moved in its favour; in response, RASK is
now guided at +2.5% for the full year (previous: +3.5%). Ex-fuel CASK continues
to be guided down 1%.

hornblower @curious - margin pressure will be the same but probably not the risk weighting misjudgement
VV75 thank you
undefined
Pharma @BornCynic the Y2K bug would have killed a lot of stuff without the intensive efforts to fix it. It's not entirely clear what needs fixing in the event of no deal beyond instructing our own customs officials to keep checks to the same level they are now.
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

On Metro, second question first .... the general belief is that the issues aren't sector wide.

Pharma (important stuff like Euratom and air traffic control have largely been sorted, at least in the short term)
BE12:06pm

Here's Goldman to explain:

BE12:06pm

Firstly, we note that Metro Bank currently reports all credit risk under the standardised approach. Larger banks, in contrast, are on an advanced approach, which means they have risk-models which are reviewed and vetted by the regulator.
Secondly, the change in risk-weights was based on an internal review of loans rather than a general upward pressure on risk weights. The risk-weights associated with each bucket within the standardised approach haven’t changed, nor has the bank reported a deterioration in asset quality which could have led to an increase in RWAs.
For the larger UK banks, we see the review of mortgage risk weights as one of the main upward pressures on RWAs. This review is expected to come into force in 3Q20 and we have incorporated its impact in our estimates.

12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

And on the second point, it simply doesn't make sense from a valuation perspective to raise capital by issuing shares at sub book to fund expansion.

Soundbuy Cheers all
BE12:10pm

The model relies on the stock trading at a premium to book.

Penny metro: exactly - cut the book rather than raise money-losing capital
undefined
12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

What are we missing?

BE12:11pm

Didn't mention Rhythmone, which was late-in-the-day Ben story: https://www.betavi...rhythmone-said-to/

BE12:11pm

Basically, they're doing it again.

12:11 pm
BE12:12pm

Another all-share merger.

Penny Feels like we havent discussed the sale of Fullers brewing ops. I feel like the ROTR could have a lot of opinions on the matter
Penny may be one for a friday session..
BE12:12pm

With another company no one outside the grim, grimy and highly suspicious world of video adverts has heard of.

BE12:12pm

Taptica this time.

PBateman annoyed as was going to buy fullers for the 15% perk the other day
PBateman 15% off*
12:14 pm
BE12:15pm

And, as ever with Blinkx as was, it's an odd structure. This one's an all-share takeover of RhythmOne by Taptica where Taptica retains the name and management.

BE12:15pm

And for all the bluster in certain channels about taking on the might of Google and etc, it looks like a cost cutting sack half the staff deal.

BE12:16pm

Anyway, that's that. Shares going worse.

Pharma @PBateman - they are keeping the pubs and hotels, so should still be valid
12:16 pm
RhythmOne PLC (RTHM:LSE): Last: 166.03, down 21.17 (-11.31%), High: 189.20, Low: 166.03, Volume: 447.54k
undefined
hornblower @PB 15% off beer?
BE12:17pm

We done? I think we are.

Pharma @hornblower - food and drinks at managed pubs and hotels
GBKrona thanks @BE, ROTR.
PBateman ^ he knows
PBateman cheers all
FATDAZ Thanks All espec BE
12:17 pm
BE12:17pm

@Penny, been meaning to do the Fullers deal for a while. It's really, really hard to justify the valuation unless you factor in that big riverside property in Chiswick.

Penny I think FTAV ML was borked last friday, hence we missed a discussion on it.
BE12:19pm

The Japanese have made noises that really don't add up to commitments to keep on brewing there. But, really, either the market's very wrong about the valuations of old man bitter or the brewery is a considerable attraction.

BE12:20pm

Marston's and a couple of others have brewery operations equivalent to London Pride but they haven't budged, in spite of the spectacular hidden value readthrough. But then, their breweries aren't Thames-side.

12:19 pm
BE12:20pm

But that's for another day.

BE12:20pm

Ta for comments. There's more here on various things: https://www.ft.com...-b329-c7e6ceb5ffdf

Viking1 Japanese spotted at Bell and Crown
BE12:20pm

Back tomorrow. Afternoon all.
